item.title: Docebo Inc: Leading the Organizational Learning Trend in a Digital Savvy-economy
item.description: Company analysis & growth drivers
item.dc:creator: Francis
item.content:encoded:
Hello Everyone;

Hope you are having a good Friday. We will continue featuring all the companies highlighted on my Top 30 Companies to watch in 2021.

—-

Over the next couple of weeks, we’ll be talking about the digital transformation happening within the education and online learning ecosystem. Today, we’ll focus on the learning happening within corporations. Docebo - another fast-growing Canadian company which provides the core technologies for companies to effectively help employees learn new skills in a digital economy.

Investment Thesis Summary:

  • Digital learning is the lifeblood of any innovative and growing organization.

  • As new technologies continue developing everyday, the more learning requirements would be imposed on organizations and employees allowing them to select providers such as Docebo

  • Docebo was selected as one of the fastest innovative companies by Deloitte Fast 50 - One of Deloitte's 2020 Enterprise Fast 15 for the Technology Fast 50™ and Fast 500™ Winners.

  • Docebo has shown execution and proved their credibility by winning major clientele such as Uber, Amazon, Walmart etc.

  • Docebo continues to grow revenues consistently at over 55% while expanding gross margins within the 80% range.

The Industry - What is happening?

As mentioned, learning is the lifeblood of an organization’s culture and development. Similar to how an individual grows when they learn daily, the same analogy applies to an organization that prioritizes learning. It is the key to organizational innovation and growth.

In a world with or without a pandemic. Learning is no longer about a bringing an expert or having employees travel to a different city for conferences, seminars or talks to learn new topics. Today, most individuals learn through self-directed learning. Employees learn by watching courses on their computer or by doing. It is convenient as you can easily keep up pace with your learning style.  As shown below, majority learning occurs through informal methods such as social/coaching meanwhile, the formal is only around 10%.

In Mckinsey’s top trends that will define 2021 - Workforce development was a priority. They mention that this was a big topic even before the digital-savvy pandemic. In a similar McKinsey survey conducted in May 2019, almost 90 percent of the executives and managers surveyed said their companies faced skill gaps or expected to in the next five years, hence, we can see the case for why organizations will be investing into this areas over the upcoming years. More information on this research can be found here.

Now, let’s look at an emerging winner leading this sector from Canada.

Company Overview - Docebo Inc:

Ticker Symbol: TSE: “DCBO.TO” , NASDAQ “DCBO”

Docebo is a Canadian-based company that offers cloud-based e-learning and training platform primarily across North America and Europe. They provide an easy-to-use customizable learning platform with the capabilities required to train internal and external workforces, partners and customers.

Docebo’s software allows customers to take control of their desired training for employees and retain institutional knowledge through courses and training. Organizations can centralize a broad range of learning materials and offer E-Learning solutions, such as employee onboarding, development, partner training, sales enablement, social and customer training.

The software ensures efficient online course delivery and the tracking of learning progress with advanced reporting tools and analytics. The platform is robust in that it helps customers centralize a broad range of learning materials from peer enterprises and learners into one Learning management software(LMS) to expedite and enrich the learning process.

Docebo Product lines:

The three main platforms include:  

  1. Docebo Learn – This is their foundational module, it helps learning administrators like HR centralize, organize and distribute learning content, track certifications and measure results with customer analytics.

  2. Docebo Discover, Coach & Share – It provides learners with access to social learning by encouraging the sharing of knowledge through formal, social, interactive and experiential learning across an organization.

  3. Docebo Extended Enterprises – It allows businesses to manage multiple portals for different audiences or organizations with their own administration, branding and authentication.

Other Core Platforms:

Docebo for Salesforce - This is their learning platform that integrates and leverages Salesforce’s API and technology architecture to produce a learning experience that is uniform.

Docebo - Mobile application publisher Go.Learn: This platforms allows developers to create their own branded version of Docebo mobile learning application and publish it as their own in Apple’s App Store, the Google Play Store or in their own Apple Store for Enterprise thus empowering programmers.

Docebo Virtual Coach is an AI-powered assistant that engages with learners through a conversational user interface that sends push notifications about content or learning activities to be completed and makes personalized content recommendations, amongst other tasks.

Docebo Customers & Clientele:

Over the years, Docebo’s learning platform has become the chosen platform for some major enterprises in North America and Europe. The company focuses mostly on large enterprises. So far, they include Amazon’s AWS, Uber, BMW, Walmart, Docu-sign. A couple of the big names are shown below:

It’s impressive that in Docebo’s early years that they would become the preferred platforms for these big organizations.

In early 2019 – they had just 1,600 customers with an average contract value (ACV) over $21,000 per client. This number has increased —-> to over 2,025 customers in 2020 with the most recent ACV around $32,000. This represents a 27% growth rate in customers and contract value 48% respectively. Remarkably, they have maintained a consistent Net Dollar Retention Rate >100%+ since 2019. This means they have consistently being able to continue to upsell their existing customers to buy more products.

Key Competitive Advantages/Business Strategy:

There are four major competitive advantages that I believe distinguishes Docebo to be a winner within this industry:

  1. User generated content:

  • I draw a comparison with YouTube in success -- The search giant’s success is based on the premise that all visitors come to YouTube to search and find something that matters to them. Some come to watch short clips, long-forms or how-to video. The second part is that users are empowered and feel they can contribute to the platforms success by uploading content and even making an income from it. Thirdly, YouTube has a great AI algorithm that consistently recommends new videos that are suited to your needs. Docebo’s platform serves all three purposes, slightly less on the monetization part.

  • Docebo platform is built around the premise of empowering the user or enterprise. After all my review, this is consistent. Docebo builds the foundational work — the owner/enterprise has the freedom to do anything on the platform such as creating their own applications. To this, Docebo empowers the user or enterprise to upload their content rather than just being a “watch-only” platform, the learner can even upload videos on topics they know well for others.

  1. Social collaboration elements: Docebo’s platform is built around the notion that 70% of learning is in the form of social learning rather than solely an instructor-led learning. Hence, the platform makes it easy to create, upload & share with peers. They make it enticing with rewards and relative ranking amongst peers. They allow the collaboration to extend to external organizations which is unique.

  2. The structure of large contracts and recurring revenues: The way the company is set-up is that customers sign contracts to be locked in for multiple years which then provides recurring revenue streams to the company annually. This gives Docebo good visibility into future revenues. Together with these long-term contracts, it increases the switching/opportunity costs for an enterprise moving between platforms once Docebo’s platform is core to the organization for years.

  3. Leading Industry Ratings:

    • As indicated, Docebo was announced as One of Deloitte's 2020 Enterprise Fast 15 for the Technology Fast 50™ and Fast 500™ Winners. The program recognizes Canada’s fastest-growing technology companies with the highest revenue-growth percentage over the past four years.

    • Fosway research group ranked their LMS System as a Core Leader for Learning systems. This should further enhance their competitive position. (sorry if the picture is blurry - zoom in)

  4. The ease of use and AI features embedded: As mentioned, central to the platform is its flexibility. Docebo focuses on making its platform easy to use and the enterprise/user has a lot of power to adjust the software to their preferences. Docebo is also very focused on using AI and machine learning algorithms to improve the recommendations on the application, so it is easier for users to find content that cater to them as shown below. It will be interesting to observe this feature overtime.

Financials:

Revenue is generated on multi-year contract subscription and prepaid on an annual basis.

Revenue $/Growth rate figures:

1. - 2016 Revenue: >$10M

2. - 2017 Revenue: >$17M —>  Growth Rates over 74%

3. - 2018 Revenue: >$27M —> (58%)

4. - 2019 Revenues >$41M —> (53%)

5. - 2020 Revenues (TTM) - $56.5M —> (54%)

** 94% of the revenues are annual recurring revenues (ARR) slashed out over a number of months. Going forward, analysts are forecasting a 45% sales growth forecast over the year of 2021.

Margins:

They have been successful at improving their Gross margins (which was already above-average) from 75% in 2017 ---> to 82% in 2020! For new investors, it just means Docebo has to spend less on the costs required to provide a service to their customers, allowing them to earn more money even as they grow. This is key.

They also have been improving their Free cash-flow margins which was negative (21%) in 2017 ---> (1%) in 2020. This just means the company is able to generate more cash from their operations and distribute it across the business overtime.

The company is not yet profitable (-13% EBITDA margins). However, they have shown massive improvement striving towards profitability. Once profitability sets in 2021/22 on my expectation, I expect much more bigger moves on the stock. Some of key drivers that will help their financial profile include:

  • Increasing deal sizes and contracts with customers

  • Back office automation, infrastructure and technologies will be key to enhancing efficiencies to scale the business.

The Industry and Market Opportunity:

According to various sources and Docebo, the global e-learning market is expected to reach $29.9billion by 2025 from $9.5B in 2019 – that is a 22% CAGR. It shows that they have a big market opportunity to win ahead of them if they continue executing.

By 2031, the World Economic Forum estimates that 80% of new jobs will require AI-literacy. How can institutions get ready to fill these AI roles without a great LMS?

In 2018, the World Economic Forum estimated that more than half of employees would need significant reskilling or upskilling by 2022.  More evidence from Mckinsey shows that the benefits of reskilling current staff, rather than letting them go and then finding new people, typically costs less and brings benefits that outweigh the costs. Investing in employees can also foster loyalty, customer satisfaction, and positive brand perception. (zoom in closer)

Management team:

There is a very healthy management ownership. Jason Chapnik founded the company. He is currently the Chairman of the Board and CEO of Intercap, this corporation is a majority shareholder of Docebo with a 51% Ownership stake. Meanwhile, the current CEO, Claudio Erba who has been leading the company since 2014 owns around 4% of the company. This gives a solid 55% leadership ownership stake into the company.

Risks/Competition:

  • Direct Competition against Blackboard Community and Canvas Learning management infrastructure. These two companies also provide learning management systems, but these providers seem to focus more on the educational industry. Meanwhile Docebo is focused on the enterprise market. It will be interesting to observe if they pivot to the enterprise market, but I doubt it as Docebo has a solid expertise in this market.

  • In-direct Competition from other learning platforms: Docebo also faces indirect competition with the likes of Massive Open Online Courses (MOOC) platforms. These are free or cheap courses provided by Udemy, Coursera, 2U Inc etc. The bear case is if employees or corporations decide to use external platforms for their employee learning and development. With the flexibility of Docebo’s platform, I doubt the biggest enterprise will go and look for pre-built platforms like a Coursera.

  • The current vs future investment into LMS by organizations: As much as the best and innovative organizations prioritize learning as a priority for their corporation. We need to ask the question how much current investment by companies affected badly will be placed on learning systems by more organizations in a pandemic or will the spending be prioritized for a future date. Does it affect Docebo. This will be important to watch, but so far Docebo grew their business and market opportunity last year despite the pandemic.

Growth drivers/future growth:

  1. Up-selling existing customer base: It will be important to see how much Docebo can continue to increase their upselling and scale amongst their existing customer base. An example will be increasing their business within other lines of business for Amazon, Walmart or Uber.

  2. Capitalizing on leading industry ratings and high-profile customers should further allow them to reach and expand their customer base to get more clients.

  3. Geographic expansion across Europe and Asia – Docebo has highlighted plans to continue to expand their business beyond Europe and other aspects of Asia. This will be important to watch especially since they have a strong presence in Italy.

  4. New product launches: Docebo plans to expand their product offerings so as to cover the entire learning management landscape. Two core areas include — a) Course Builder: an automatic AI that creates online courses from unique web sources b) Learning Analytics: an easy way to use analytics to evaluate learning progress that can advance better decision making for individual learners or as a corporation in general.

  5. Strategic alliances/Acquisitions: The company is planning for more opportunistic acquisition or strategic alliances to help them achieve this goal of expanding their offerings, so this is important news to watch over the next months.

Bottom Line/Summary:

Modern workers are feeling the pressure to skill up, with one in three working Americans (32%) saying they feel pressure to learn new tech-related skills to protect their jobs. Nearly half (49%) of workers in multiple countries believe training in using new technology would help them increase their chances of a promotion or raise. We all know this :)

As automation, increased digitalization and technologies take over more corporations. There will be an increased need for better learning tools for employees to keep up on the digital economy. Almost all major corporations are racing to ensure their employees can pick-up new skills to keep up pace with technology.

Docebo has executed successfully by consistently growing their top line business. They have won some of the biggest customers in North America. They also have some of the best industry ratings with regard to their technology offering. Going forward, it will be important to watch if competition affects them overtime or growth slows down.

Docebo has begun building an important moat within this sector. Currently valued around a small $2-billion market cap, Docebo has all the potential to provide a 5-7x return over the next five years!

All corporations have important learning and development goals for their employees because it is only human for employees to seek growth in their careers. The virus has reduced travelling for conferences; hence, employees are doing most of their learning on computers. Docebo will continue to be a major beneficiary of this trend and they will be an interesting company to watch over the next year!

Thank you for reading. Have a good weekend everyone! Let me know if you ever have any questions or feedback!

item.title: Goodfood Market Corp: A leading online grocery provider in Canada growing rapidly
item.description: Full Company Analysis
item.dc:creator: Francis
item.content:encoded:
Hello Everyone,

Today, we have a full analysis on Goodfood Market Corp. I posted a Twitter thread on our Twitter page with a general overview of the company. For those that do not have a Twitter account, this is an opportunity to read more about the company.

Goodfood Market ranks as one of the fastest growing companies on the Toronto Stock Exchange in Canada, growing at triple digits ( whooping 267%+ Compounded Growth) and is currently benefiting from the trend towards online grocery shopping and less consumer visits to the grocery store. They were added to the S&P/TSX small cap and selected to the TSX 30 as one of the top performing stocks in 2020. We’ll get to know more about them.

INDUSTRY TRENDS – Online Grocery Shopping:

I would like to begin by looking at what is happening big picture before we conduct our deep dive. How often or convenient has it been to get to the grocery store since March? The online grocery industry is among the fastest growing industries in the world.

The pandemic has made people reluctant to visit stores. Further, because of restrictions and lockdowns (especially since December in Canadian major cities like Montreal and Toronto). For some consumers, the reluctance is as a result of the need to avoid large crowds in shopping malls such as amongst the much older/health sensitive individuals at risk. This has further boosted eCommerce and online shopping. The heightened growth has been spurred by a sharp acceleration in penetration driven by a rise in first-time users of online shoppers for groceries.

In 2015, Only around 15% of Canadians purchased groceries online, a number which rose to 25% in 2017, but reached 55% as of March 2020. As the data below shows, the Total Addressable Market (TAM) for online shopping is now forecasted to grow by 56% CAGR through 2025 as more people embrace getting their groceries delivered. More data can be seen below:

Also, pre-pandemic, the worldwide online grocery market was expected to grow by more than US$227 billion over the next five years, more than doubling in size to US$374.9 billion. In Canada, before the pandemic, less than 1% of Canadian’s shopping for C$124 billion worth of items took place online. Initially, that penetration was expected to increase at a 21% CAGR to over C$2 billion by 2023, largely driven by changing consumer expectations and technology innovation. However, the current pandemic has shifted growth expectations upwards and timelines forward. Growth initially planned to occur in 5 years is forecasted to occur in less than 3 years.

The online grocery market in Canada is now estimated to have reached approximately C$6 billion. Grocery incumbents and emerging players alike are quickly building a wide range of product lines and concepts (e.g., “Grocerant”) to cater to the increasingly busy lifestyles of Canadians nationwide and those working from home.

The charts below show the transformation happening and the growth in online grocery shift accelerating specifically to the Canadian market as well as in the United states. There is still so much run-way for growth in the industry.

Now, let’s review the company that is taking advantage of this transformation within this industry in Canada.

GOODFOOD MARKET CORP.

Ticker Symbol on the TSE/TSX: FOOD, FOOD.TO

Overview:

Goodfood Market Corp is an online grocery company that delivers fresh meals, ingredients, meal-kit and grocery products in Canada. The company offers ready-to-eat and breakfast meals, including ready-to-blend smoothies and other breakfast items, prepared meals, cooked meats and sides, salads and soups; and private-label grocery items in various categories, such as bakery, dessert, meat and seafood, drinks, pantry, produce, snacks, dairy, and kitchen essentials, as well as olive oil, juice, and chocolate cookies.

The company also offers ready-made breakfast meals for delivery. Goodfood vision is to make the impossible come true from farm to the kitchen. They want to be in “every kitchen” as the main source of meals for consumers.

Simple product overview:

It is a subscription-based business, as long as you subscribe as a new member on their website platform.

Ideally, the customer goes on the makegoodfood website, selects their mix of grocery and meal orders —> Goodfood dispatches the orders from its 100+ direct farming relationships, partners and suppliers or utilizes what they have at their operational centers —> The Fulfilment and delivery is then dispatched to the subscribers —> fresh products arrive with the step-by-step “Ready-to-cook” instructions and on back-end, payments are made to suppliers within 90-days.

The value proposition is to take the hassle out of cooking, save time, offering competitive pricing and making it easy for subscribers to prepare meals at home every week. As shown below, they have a wide variety of selections for consumers.

PRODUCT LINE:

Goodfood WOW: The company launched “Goodfood WOW,” a new unlimited same-day grocery delivery service starting gradually in Montreal. An analyst remarked, that “same-day delivery was the next logical step for Goodfood in its pursuit of a larger share of the food-at-home opportunity.” This new service strengthens the company’s value proposition as same-day delivery is essential since this is consistent with the quick turnaround consumers expect for grocery shopping and delivery. Also, it leads to repeated orders for more products.

Faster delivery times are a clear differentiator compared to the competition. The launch is timely given the accelerated penetration of online grocery shopping in Canada since the beginning of the pandemic. This product should support the company’s next phase of growth. Goodfood is also one of the first companies to offer same-day delivery service in the meal kit industry. Capgemini industry research shows “75% of consumers say they would spend and shop more frequently with a retailer that offered timely delivery of online grocery orders.”

BUSINESS STRATEGY & VALUE PROPOSITION:

When we consider an grocery shopper wanting to pick between ordering online versus going to the store like Walmart, some of the most important factors for shoppers would include the following; (I highlight how Goodfood plans to utilize these factors for their strategy):

  1. Location: One factor on the consumer’s mind is the proximity, distance and convenience to arrive at the store. Online shopping eliminates the issue of travel as long as you are sure the grocery will arrive when you need it. On Goodfood’s path, the company has built 7 major production factories across Western and Eastern Canada with a capacity to serve over 35M Canadians across the big cities and the ability to gross over $1billion in sales. The company aims to become more vertically integrated so as to control more of the supply chain since this is very important in food delivery.

  2. Price: Another key factor is the price of the grocery. Most shoppers care about lower costs as much as possible. Goodfood offers very competitive prices than their competitors and aims to match stores like Walmart. This has been achieved by offering lower prices on certain items driven by fulfilment and delivery density.

  3. Selection: Increasing the variety of food selection is very important to the consumer, so they don’t feel like they can’t find certain key items. Goodfood offers a wide product offering of over 4000 items and 400+ Goodfood branded products. However, this is still an area the company needs to improve upon when compared to the competition.

  4. Ease of use of the technology: The ability for consumers to use the eCommerce store. It is important for consumers to be able to easily use the website to quickly enter their orders. So far, Goodfood has a done job by attracting high-volume of monthly visits on their website for shopping amongst most of the other food delivery companies in Canada.

Goodfood Go-to-Market Strategy:

  • Aggressive marketing to grow subscribers —> Increase selection variety and minimal food waste in the supply-chain process —> Lower delivery cost and delivery speed —> Increase scale of reach —> Invest in automation to improve cost margins —> Drive profits per subscriber by upselling overtime.

  • Targeting millennials and becoming a core brand for millennial family households overtime.

  • Well-recognized brand amongst this category of shoppers. So far, the company has been successful. Goodfood currently owns 40-45% market share of the online grocery market in Canada.

  • Capitalize on the shift to healthy eating as most of their meals come directly from the farm.

Customer Growth is accelerating:

The strategy appears to be working, below we can see the phenomenal increase in customer growth:

  • 2018: 89,000+ Customer Subscribers

  • 2019: 111,000+ Customer Subscribers

  • January 2020: 200,000+ Customer Subscribers

  • December 2020: 306,000+ Customer Subscribers

This growth is impressive, at over 100% YoY. Goodfood has consistently been achieving 20% / monthly growth prior to the pandemic. This demonstrates continued strong investment and execution in growth as it penetrates the Canadian e-commerce grocery and meal solutions markets.

THE FINANCIALS:

Goodfood is in a great financial position. The customer growth has translated to financial growth rates and the chart below shows the revenue figures:

  • 2017: 606%

  • 2018: 256%

  • 2019: 128%

  • 2020: 77%

  • The 4-YR Compounded Annual Growth Rate is 266.75%

Quarterly Year-over-Year Growth Rate:

  • Q1 2020 - 90%, Q2 2020 - 61%, Q3 2020 - 73%, Q4 2020 - 85%

  • Recent, Q1-2021 (62%)

  • It is important to always track the growth rates of a company. We can see that Goodfood’s sales growth has steadily been increasing, however, it is slightly declining overtime as the business gets larger. In general, any growth figure over 55% is above-average, so this is still very impressive.

Professional analysts forecast 35% growth rate for the full-year 2020. The highest analyst growth forecast are for $397M (36% Growth) in 2021 and to $465M (63% Growth) in 2022. Personally, I believe these forecasts are low and will be revised overtime.

Gross margins:

The margins are extremely low at around 30% due to the high-cost of their manufacturing centers, food production etc. However, we have to observe that they have been improving those margins overtime. Due to the high top-line revenue growth and investment into automation, I believe this margins will improve overtime. The improvement in Gross Margins shown below:

Latest Company Developments - FY Q1, 2021 - Earnings Report Analysis:

Goodfood announced the latest company developments on Tuesday, January 13th, 2020. Below are some of the key highlights:

  • Revenue Growth – 62% YoY

  • Revenue Expected ($87M) vs Actual ($91.4M)

  • Expected EPS (-0.07) vs Actual (-0.04) [Due to seasonal costs]

  • Gross Margins: 2019 (30%) vs 2020 (32%)

  • EBITDA Margins: Expected ($0.5M) vs Actual of $1.4M (+137% Improvement) YoY.

  • High Cost: Goodfood costs have risen due to a demand for all products; especially in operations and labor, but those are easing.

  • Quarterly cash flow from operating activities was $2.1 million, an improvement of $0.7 million compared to the same period last year, and Goodfood ended the quarter with a strong cash balance of $104.1 million.

MANAGEMENT TEAM:

Jonathan Ferrari , Neil Cuggy and Raffi Krikorian were all founders of the company back in 2014. Jonathan and Neil worked previously as Investment bankers at RBC Capital. They were recognized as EY Young Entrepreneurs of the year 2018. The Co-founders own over 30% of the company shares and the rest of the management owns around 10% giving a strong 40% ownership stake in the company! This excellent ownership stake in the company gives shareholders confidence that the company will make good long-term decisions in favour of investors.

I will note that the company won the “Most Trusted Meal Kit Delivery Service” based on a research by a top market market firm.

Key risks to observe:

  • Cyclicality of the business: During summer, holiday and popular vacation periods, revenues are lower, as a higher proportion of subscribers elect to skip meal delivery services, since they may be on holidays or away from home. Further, the growth rate of subscribers is also negatively affected during these periods. The winter months are the strongest. I’ll note that they adjust the cost-basis to adjust for this impact.

  • Low gross margins: It will be important to keep watching how Goodfood improves their gross margin and EBITDA margins. This will be important if they are to achieve further scale.

  • Competitors from international companies like HelloFresh global meal-kit market leader, HelloFresh Group (HFG-XE) have a larger scale, geographic diversity of their business and they are gradually claiming market share gains. However, Goodfood is the major leader in this category.

  • Some direct and indirect competitors include: (a) the supermarkets/ food retailers, (b) other meal kit companies, (c) restaurants, (d) food manufacturers and (e) food delivery businesses/ grocery delivery companies in Canada such as Sobey’s, Walmart etc.

  • Adverse conditions and effects with the food industry: inflation worries and higher labour costs and possible cuts in the supply chains.

BOTTOM LINE:

There is no doubt that a pandemic that ravaged society for more than 9-months has caused a major behavioural change as a significant percentage of traditional grocery shopping has permanently shifted online. We have observed that a large portion of food consumption is moving from restaurants to grocery/home meal solutions. Goodfood had been growing over 100% prior to the pandemic, so I’ll imagine this period will further spur their growth as they help consumers with food delivery.

Goodfood believes there are significant opportunities to continue to rapidly grow its subscriber base and basket sizes by investing in highly targeted marketing campaigns, capacity expansion and investments in technology automation. There may be risks associated with the strong competition from some incumbents as well as how well they can improve their margins. I am confident that their investment in production facilities and automation will further help in this direction.

I look at Goodfood as a young “Amazon fresh” for food delivery building a moat with a strong brand connection for consumers with opportunities for international expansion. The more people have to stay home longer and restrict their movements outside, the higher the convenience and willingness amongst shoppers to embrace new behaviors in online shopping, leading to permanent behavioural changes at home. Goodfood is innovating within this space and I’m confident they are in a great position to capitalize on this trend into the future.

Have a great weekend! Next week, we have another interesting company coming up from our top picks selection!

What do you think? Would you be willing to order your grocery online? Let me know your thoughts!

item.title: Top Companies to watch in 2021!
item.description: Big Themes and Emerging trends to watch
item.dc:creator: Francis
item.content:encoded:
Happy New Year Everyone!

Here are our top picks for 2021!

Introduction:

We wanted to share our best stock picks and ideas for 2021. There are no certainties as 2020 has shown, but we believe that these companies and their stocks are poised for success due to the rapid innovation and industry tailwinds from 2020.

Many companies reported exceptional performance over the last year. To try to name each one of them would be an exhaustive exercise. Hence, I have selected a niche group of companies based on the following criteria and filters:

  1. Small and medium capitalization companies: Generally, small market cap companies fall into the category of (<$300b – $2 billion) and mid-cap companies fall into the ($2b - $10 billion) category. I put more focus on the latter category because data shows that as the economy gradually recovers from major shocks, small caps outperform their larger counterparts in post-elections by about 4%. Secondly, identifying small caps in great competitive position with exceptional products early into their story can provide the biggest stock upside returns. For example, can you imagine buying Tesla shares just four years ago at $35?

  2. Consistency of revenue/sales growth: We are after companies where the last twelve-months of revenues and sales growth have accelerated over 30% year-over-year consistently and the future professional analysts growth forecast is high compared to historical. It is important to note that whenever analysts forecast future growth of about 15% for a stock, this is generally considered very good (more discussion about this later). Specifically, our focus is on companies that will grow regardless of whether there is a pandemic or not.

  3. Leadership team: Companies whose founders, CEO’s and management teams are considered visionaries and hold significant shares of the company. This augurs well for external shareholder returns because leaders make long-term decisions in the interest of the investors.

  4. Focus on innovation and disruptive technologies: We are interested in companies that are disrupting new industries that will thrive over the next decade.

  5. Official analyst’s growth forecast: Professional analysts interviews with the executive management teams of these companies, reviews of earning calls, participation in analyst and investor meetings presented by the company.  Analysts factor in massive amounts of information into their modelling before making future predictions. No one is perfect in the market with predictions, however, the forecast can give us a “guide” or “glimpse” of what to expect in 2021.

  6. Slight emphasis on Canadian brands: I would be showcasing some of the best stories in Canada since we have a large Canadian subscriber audience.

P/S: The compilation of the names of these companies are based off results from research from reviewing multiple companies and industry reports. I have used stock symbol abbreviations throughout the article, so feel free to google the symbols and you’ll find the companies immediately.  All the links attached for every company directs you to where you can find in-depth analysis on those companies.

Big Picture Company Overview:

Here is a broad overview of all the companies that will be discussed in this article:

I have identified three categories of stocks, the top picks and the justification for selection.

First Category:

Telemedicine:

The foremost trend is Telemedicine - After reviewing multiple industry reports, there is consistency that telehealth is here to stay. The figures for telemedicine and virtual health are just striking. I’ll review a few here. Another data recently from the CNBC, showed that in 2019, total virtual healthcare visits in the US were 96,000, but in 2020 total virtual visits were over 18,000,000 million, representing almost a 19,000% increase. There is no doubt some of these changes will remain for an exceptionally long time.

The Federal Communications Commission is spending $200 million to improve connectivity between patients and virtual-healthcare providers, and the US Department of Health and Human Services has increased reimbursements for telemedicine. It has also allowed the provision of virtual care. Sweden’s KRY International, one of Europe’s biggest telehealth providers, reported that registrations were up more than 200 percent. France and Korea have both updated regulations to ease access to telemedicine. All based on global extensive studies conducted by McKinsey in their 2020 report. With the circulation of the vaccine to the general populace at least months away, patients and healthcare providers both have reasons to expand virtual interactions. A healthcare expert, Fisher believes that telehealth could account for 30 percent of all healthcare visits in the future. Governments have and will continue to invest significantly into healthcare

My favorite picks are CloudMD “DOC.TO” and Well Health “WELL.TO” , not only because of telemedicine but their digitization efforts across Canadian healthcare. In both of those articles, I provided reasons why I opted for those names. I would like to recognize Teladoc Health (TDOC) as one of the best leaders within this space in North America. However, we are after stocks with significant upside that can give us 10x returns with less competition. I believe these Canadian companies have a good competitive position in Canada including great management teams and solid strategic plans with a history of successful acquisitions ahead

eCommerce and Payments:

In nine of 13 major countries surveyed by McKinsey, at least two-thirds of consumers have tried new forms of shopping. And in all 13, 65 percent or more explained they intend to continue to do so. Mckinsey also states that in developing markets - Brazil and India, for example - the pandemic will accelerate digital shopping, albeit from a “low base” - this is why I like StoneCo (STNE) and even other high-quality names like Sea Limited (SE) because these countries still have low eCommerce usage.

e-Commerce was already meaningfully and visibly eating into the sales of brick-and-mortar stores. What the pandemic has done is to accelerate a change in shopping habits that was already well established. Early indications from China based on the McKinsey study, are that new customers and markets - specifically individuals aged 36 and over and residents of smaller cities - have begun to shop online in greater numbers. In Europe, 13 percent of consumers said in early April that they were planning to browse online for the first time. Specifically, the shift to online retail is real, and much of it is here to stay. In the United States, the penetration of e-commerce was forecast in 2019 to reach 24 percent by 2024; by July 2020, it had hit 33 percent of total retail sales. To put it another way, the first half of 2020 saw an increase in e-commerce equivalent to that of the previous ten years”.

My favorite name in this sector is ETSY, which is a marketplace for buyers and sellers to buy or sell goods online. ETSY has recorded over 100% growth throughout the pandemic period (which began with the sales of masks). Etsy is an upcoming player in its space with strong brand recognition. Special mention to Shopify - also the leader in this category, but ETSY could provide significant upside in comparison. The fintech and payments providers will be the major beneficiaries.

Consumer products:

Celsius (CELH) is a leading healthy energy drink provider. The company has been growing exponentially. As the economy reopens and consumer spending increase, I can see the company benefiting significantly. In addition, there could be lasting changes to consumer attitudes towards health choices and Celsius has a good chance of becoming the next Monster Energy. Increased health awareness and a corresponding desire to live more healthily could bring lasting change to where, how, and what people eat. I also encourage everyone to look at names within the consumer staples industries - lots of beneficiaries.

Cybersecurity:

Another impressive sector that cannot be ignored is Cybersecurity. This is a significant area that will continue to grow irrespective of the pandemic. Towards the end of last year, the US Government experienced one of its biggest hacks in history. This exposed the weaknesses of security in government and corporations, thereby making everyone realize the need for increased spending on preventing these hacks. As more companies move to the cloud due to digital transformations, more urgency and importance will be placed on cybersecurity to protect data. Crowdstrike “CRWD” and ZScaler “ZS” are the major leaders in North America, both generating revenues over 85%+ and 52%+ quarter over quarter respectively. The cybersecurity software industry rates them higher than their peers. Since this industry would do well, I am also watching QLYS and SAIL as other attractive names with potential upsides in the Data Governance area.

Cloud Infrastructure and Analytics:  

A number of executives reported that they moved 20 to 25 times faster than they thought possible on issues such as moving to the cloud, transitioning fully online and improving data security because the pandemic forced them to do so in March and April. The charting the path to normal chart by Mckinsey depicts data points to show that the transition and digitization is really happening in 2020 based on surveys done:

Cloudfare (NET) is one of my best picks in this sector. This company provides web infrastructure, security, and performance services for organizations. This is a highly innovative company that keeps launching new products and software for clients. In 2021, I believe they will cater for small and medium-sized businesses as a huge part of their customer base providing all the services required as more businesses move to the cloud. Also, I believe that, as the economy reopens, many will prioritize the needs of Cloudfare. Special mention here also goes to DataDog (DDOG) - this is one of the major leaders in cloud transformation that provides data monitoring to companies transitioning to the cloud.

Palantir (PLTR) is already well documented within my earlier post. In a nutshell, this is a company that is providing lots of essential services to the government because of the Covid-19 pandemic. The technology has played a key role in contact tracing, drug developments, and not to mention the Data Analytics and Artificial intelligence work they provide for many government agencies in DC. In recent times, the company has been winning multiple new contracts and I believe the biggest growth driver is the moment they expand to the private sector in 2021.

Dye and Durham (DND) is a cloud-based company that provides many essential services to legal and real-estate departments as well as helping to digitize these sectors to the cloud. Clientele includes the top-20 law firms and big banks. I believe there is tremendous growth ahead in 2021 as the economy reopens.  

Lemonade (LMND) is an insurance company that I have written extensively about, so I won’t go into lots of details. I believe that after the shock from the pandemic, more people will realize the need for insurance. Further, Lemonade has some new products lined up this year and last week, announced a milestone of reaching more than 1million new members. There is tremendous growth ahead in 2021.

Below are the analyst’s growth rate forecasts for the companies mentioned above:

Second category of top picks:

·        Housing trends: many people are moving into the suburban areas from the big cities. Opendoor Technologies (OPEN) is disrupting how home owners can quickly sell their homes and Expi world holdings (EXPI) is innovating the traditional real-estate brokerage system. I have attached two of the best resources in the link above.

·        Digitization of online learning and education: the biggest beneficiaries from this trend are both 2U Inc (TWOU) and Chegg (CHGG). I have previously done some research on 2U as it was one my biggest convictions in 2020. The transition to online learning is not only happening within schools, but it is happening within corporations. The biggest beneficiary in North America this year has been Docebo (DCBO), a Toronto based company which will be the focus of my next deep dive (stay tuned)

·        Sharing and gig-economy: the high levels of unemployment has made many individuals to consider selling their skills to generate either full-time or part-time income through freelance gigs. In addition, organizations have found it easier to hire cheaper talents through this platform. The biggest beneficiary is Fiverr Marketplace (FVRR). Upwork is also remarkably interesting but require better execution to match Fiverr.

·        Digital payments and Fintech trends: this is a continuation of the eCommerce trends. As the savings rates accelerate- and consumer confidence returns, so will spending, with “revenge shopping” sweeping through sectors as pent-up demand is unleashed. That has been the experience of all previous economic downturns. I am very bullish on this industry. I published a recent report on Nuvei Corporation . Also, I believe StoneCo (STNE) Shift4Payments (FOUR) and Lightspeed (LSPD) not featured could have massive upsides in 2021 since their client base will be having recoveries this year.

· Rise of cloud and edge-networks: I have discussed extensively about the Cloud. My second pick beyond Cloudfare is Fastly (FSLY), a leading cloud edge platform. The company helps organizations to improve website demands as well help keep up with complex end-user requirements by powering fast, secure, and scalable digital experiences. The company launches their proprietary edge cloud platform in 2021.

Below are the analyst’s growth forecast for the companies discussed above:

Third Category:

·        Food delivery and eCommerce trends: I have discussed some of the major trends happening across food delivery, Goodfood Rx (FOOD.TO), a Toronto based company has been executing excellently. Other eCommerce names that are doing unique things is Mohawk group holdings (MWK) and Overstock (OSTK)

·        Online car-purchase and marketplace trends: Less than 10% of respondents feel comfortable carsharing but prefer buying a car. Leader is CVNA but VRM has significant future growth potential.

·        Indoor or at-home fitness trends: This is an easier trend for everyone to understand. Peloton (PTON) is the leader in this category, but I also like NLS because the products are cheaper, received good product reviews due to the pandemic and if their growth continues, there could be significant stock upside here.

·        Digital Advertisement moving outside of traditional television (APPS, ACUUFF). Other interesting names to watch here are MGNI and FUBO

·        Other telemedicine convictions include Amwell Health (AMWL). This is a company that has been accelerating growth similar to its peers. Other interesting names in this space that I did not mention include Ontrak (OTRK) and CB2 Insights

·        Industrials & Renewable Energy: significant spending by governments towards renewable energy is benefiting a variety of companies within the clean energy space. Plug power is my favorite name in this sector (PLUG) due to their proven technology and big clienteles like Walmart. Other reputable companies not featured in this space include ENPH, FSLR and CSIQ. or names such as ENPH, FSLR, CSIQ

Below is a chart of the analyst’s growth forecast for some of the mentioned companies:

—

What happens to financials, travel, energy and industrials:

A global recovery from the pandemic due to massive government spending - synchronized global social and monetary policies by all countries in the world in the wake of the pandemic - and consumers’ high savings rate which have accumulated during the pandemic will greatly benefit economic sensitive sectors like the ones mentioned above once the economy begins recovering. The caveat is if the vaccines are successful and the new virus strain does not hold the economy back from recovering. Hence, these sectors have a high-risk to reward ratio, If the economy recovers well into the second half of 2021. Some picks here include AirBnB (ABNB), Futu Holdings (FUTU), Upstart(UPST), Canadian banks and some selective airlines.

2021 IPO’s to watch:

  • Some IPOs that I am looking forward to exploring and conducting more research on, include the likes of Affirm, Roblox, UI Path, Robinhood and Coinbase. These are exceptional companies off the surface.

—

Important factors to watch:

There are three key assumptions needed to hold true for the top picks to become big winners in 2021:

The US Federal Reserve, interest rates and money supply: The money flowing into equities has exploded. Interest rates are near zero meaning the attractiveness of stock equities vs bonds has skyrocketed. There’s simply very little yield i.e. there is nowhere else where individuals can put their money and generate a good return beyond stocks.  Money has flown out of Government bonds because they are at historical lows. Simultaneously, the government is printing stimulus money, and that has to go somewhere. If the US Federal Reserve changes their stance on interest rates and yield rates go much higher in the later half of 2021 - technology and cloud SaaS stocks could decline. We know the US Feds have mentioned no rate hikes until 2023, so we’ll keep watching.

Valuations and the relative attractiveness of SaaS /technology stocks: valuations for technology companies are stretched based on historical values, meaning that prices are above their fair value. Most of the money that was pumped into the stock market in 2020 went into technology stocks. We need to keep watching to see if major institutions begin to remove their money from technology and reallocate them to these beaten-down sectors of travel, energy and financials as the economy recovers especially with high-technology valuations, so we will keep watching.  

Digital Transformation expectations: There is an expectation that digital transformations will accelerate, meaning technology/SaaS businesses will grow faster in the short term, and potentially maintain that growth mid to long term. 2021 will truly show if technology/SaaS were successful on the company’s earnings results. We need to follow closely all the results from the company’s - I will do so on our Twitter page here.

Final words:

2021 will be an interesting year. Nobody can truly predict or anticipate the future. We can only use past data to help inform future decision-making. I am sure that throughout the year, new companies will emerge while some past big winners will disappoint. There will be big declines and big upward stock movements, be prepared. The most important thing is to focus on your financial and investing goals and stick to it.

I look forward to sharing the rest of the investing year with your support and the community over the 2021 investing year. Our team is building an application that can help new and young investors with investment research, so will be reducing our write-ups to one report every two- weeks. If you want more details on any company listed above - I am happy to answer questions or if you want a free report, feel free to email me at odumfrancis92@gmail.com.

Follow our Twitter page where we share quicker posts and updates about the companies we follow. Kindly share the report or Like it if you find found it helpful.

item.title: Nuvei Corporation: Canada's largest ever tech IPO transforming the payments and fintech industry
item.description: Comparison analysis with Shopify and Lightspeed. Does Nuvei have what it takes to become the next Shopify of Canada?
item.dc:creator: Francis
item.content:encoded:
Merry Christmas folks!

Congrats to those subscribers who got into Lemonade and Dye & Durham based on our analysis. They have been solid performances over the last couple of weeks with major institutions realizing the importance of the value proposition these companies offer. Next week, we will be off until January 5th where we will be posting our top companies (stocks) within key innovative industries to watch for in 2021.

This week for our last company analysis for 2020, we focus on a company disrupting the fintech and payments industry. We begin with a brief outline to serve as a springboard for our discussion:

  • Online businesses and digital payments have become essential to keeping many small businesses alive during the pandemic this year. Companies that provide the platform and serve as enablers to facilitate digital payments online have become more vital to help the economy.

  • Nuvei Corporation became the largest technology IPO in Canadian history on the Toronto Stock Exchange in September, bigger than Shopify and Lightspeed. Interestingly in 2020, Shopify which was founded in 2006 became the biggest company in Canada based on Market Capitalization, surpassing the value of Royal Bank of Canada. Does Nuvei have what it takes to become the next Shopify? We will discuss extensively on Nuvei and sprinkle some differences between Lightspeed and Shopify.

INDUSTRY:

Let’s begin by briefly looking at what is happening within the Financial Technology and e-Commerce industry.

  • The future of mobile commerce and e-commerce has been accelerated by Covid as we’ve heard many times in 2020. The way consumers make payments for purchases is rapidly changing. It is all about the convenience and ease for the consumer to have the ability to buy any good or services anywhere at anytime. The e-Commerce market is fueled by individuals shifting their shopping behaviors by making more online purchases.

  • New technology developments are resulting in the proliferation of the growing adoption of APM’s (alternative payment methods) such as eWallets, Mobile pay to make the customer experience better.

  • This is a massive market growing rapidly. According to eMarketer, the global mobile commerce and e-commerce market is expected to increase from $3.4 trillion in 2019 to $6.3 trillion in 2024, representing a CAGR of approximately 13%. The convergence of mobile commerce and eCommerce channels around the world is rapidly changing the way consumers pay for goods and services. The most recent data suggests we have achieved over 20% adoption already in 2020.  

COMPANY DEFINITION & BREAKDOWN:

Nuvei Corporation. Ticker Symbol “NVEI-T”  

Nuvei is a Canadian-based company that provides payments technology solutions to merchants and partners in North America, Latin America, Europe, and Asia Pacific. Nuvei provides e-commerce and merchant commerce services (transactions made on mobile devices such as cell phones).  These merchants include local businesses that are scrambling to get their businesses to sell online or a mix of online and brick-and-mortar solutions. These small businesses can sell to anyone locally or internationally. Nuvei’s secure technology platform allows merchants to accept electronic payments in approximately 150 currencies from 450 payment methods including the established partners (Mastercard and Visa) as well as alternative payment methods (such as Apple Pay, PayPal, Alipay, and Interac). Additionally, Nuvei provides end-to-end processing including Business Intelligence dashboard for retailers to understand their customer behaviour, trends and manage risks.

The company serves four main channels: Merchant-commerce, e-commerce, in-store purchases and Unattended machines (like vending machines), with most of its revenue generated from m-commerce and e-commerce.

Customers:

The company has a diversified client base serving customers across a variety of high-growth market across regulated gaming, social gaming, hospitality, online retail sector like restaurants, travel and financial services globally. The company serves over 50,000 merchants in over 200 markets worldwide. For the 12-month period ending June 30, the company’s top 10 merchants accounted for roughly 14 per cent of gross profit. As shown below, most of the merchant brands are international.

BUSINESS STRATEGY & COMPETITIVE EDGE:

Core Strategy:

  • Nuvei position themselves as a global payments technology solution provider that ensures the whole payment process is seamless. They are part of a select group of payment providers that can serve complex verticals, including regulated online gaming, regulated FX trading and regulated financial services compared t competitors.

  • International growing markets: Nuvei’s management team focuses on high-growth target markets within international markets. They acquired a company called Safe Charge for $889M (big deal) because it provides a full-service payment platform for payment growth and it allowed them to further enter into the UK market. Nuvei made another acquisition of Smart-to-pay, to allow them entry into the Dutch market including other international countries.

  • Nuvei’s key competitive advantage that differentiates it from Lightspeed, and Shopify is the fact that they have built their own proprietary native commerce platform – This is simply all the “technology” involved when you swipe your card to make a payment. Let us review it simply below — meanwhile full details can be found here:

Traditional payment solution:

The first stage is where the customer goes to the Coffeeshop to make a payment at a merchant —> this payment goes through a gateway —> your payment information then goes through multiple different providers A, B, C and D within seconds (as shown below) – these are different third-party vendor companies responsible for verifying and approving key information such as fraud detection, currency, gateway, risk management, verification of your details and acquirer information —> before payments go through the payments networks like a Visa or Mastercard which helps to route and verify your information with your home bank —> finally, it goes through the issuer (the credit card financial institution and your bank account) to give the final approval before the money is deducted from your account and slowly goes to the merchants account.

Nuvei’s payment solution:

The same process as listed above occurs, however, Nuvei has built its own core technology platform that eliminates the need to work with disparate third-party vendors (Provider A-B-C-D above) for gateway, acquiring, currency, verification and risk management while, all that process just happens under Nuvei’s system. This simplified payment methodology for Nuvei’s merchants reduces dependence on third-party vendors, cuts out costs and allows for better transparency of the process for Nuvei’s merchants. This single vendor experience is difficult to replicate for those who operate multiple platforms and differentiates them from other payment providers like Shopify or Lightspeed.  Further, through their single integration to their multi-currency pricing technology platform, merchants can securely accept payments for services sold online in nearly 150 currencies, can settle locally in over 200 markets and there are over 450 payment alternative methods. This is a core competitive advantage for Nuvei .

FINANCIALS:

Revenue breakdown - there are three main components:

  1. Nuvei collects a fee for every transaction made through their merchants (main source of revenue). The company benefits from higher sales volume and transactions from its merchants.

  2. Nuvei charges fees for processing everything in-between providing payments solutions for gateway technology and,

  3. Extra back-end & front-end value-added services such as Business Intelligence and Analytics Dashboard information.

Generally,

  • Revenues for the last couple of years (2017, 2018, 2019, YTD 2020); $124M, $149M, $245M, $259M, For the last trailing-twelve months were $338M+ with Gross profit of $205M.

  • Gross margins are at a stunning 83%. (This is due to the fact that they cut-out third-party vendors.)

  • Professional analysts forecast revenue of US$351 million in 2020, US$456-million in 2021, and US$525-million in 2022. The company is profitable on an operating profit basis but making a loss on a Net basis. Analysts are expecting the company to become profitable in 2021 with the average earnings price estimate set at $0.91 EPS on over $151M.

  • Valuation: The company’s stock is trading at a price-to-sales ratio of 30.5, this is generally high, but relative to Shopify at 60 and Lightspeed at 65, Nuvei is lower. This is also due to the slower growth from Nuvei compared to these companies.

MANAGEMENT TEAM/CULTURE:

The company is led by the company’s founder and CEO, Philip Fayer. He has a 93% approval rating on Glassdoor based off 59 reviews which is not enough, but generally suggest employees love working there with their leader. All employees received around an estimated $100,000+ of company share round from the company’s successful IPO which is really impressive.

The company has a strong shareholder base. The company’s founder, chairman and chief executive officer Philip Fayer owns over 34-million multiple voting shares. CDP Investissements Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, owns over 21-million shares. The positives are the fact that the founder still leads the company and holds a substantial amount of the company’s share ownership which hopefully align shareholder interest with the company long-term.

RISKS:

  • Negative merchant reviews compared to Lightspeed and Shopify: There have been a number of complaints made against Nuvei by merchants using its platform based on Google and independent customer reviews sites. It also appears that Nuvei has had branding issues in the past which led to them changing their name to Nuvei from Pivotal Capital Payments.

  • Extensive cost cutting: Nuvei utilizes extensive indirect and independent sales agents to attract and sell accounts to merchants. This has led to situations where a merchant has difficulty accessing someone within the company leading to complaints, and poor onboarding experiences.

  • Nuvei signs merchants up for long-term contracts with automatic renewal clause. Merchants claim there are other hidden undisclosed fees to encourage quick sign-ups.

  • Intensive competition and growth: My observation is that while Nuvei has grown well over the last two quarters, however, their year-over-year growth rates over the last couple of years is much slower than that of Lightspeed and Shopify. This signals that the intense competition within this industry could be affecting Nuvei, which could be a reason for them aiming at international market expansion.

Industry Competitors:

  • Other key industry players that compete directly and indirectly include companies like Shopify, Square, Stripe, PayPal and Lightspeed which have grown exponentially. However, more direct competitors are the ecommerce payment channels such as Adyen and PayPal and other payment processors (such as Fiserv, Global Payments, Shift4 Payments and Worldpay).

Key differences between Nuvei, Lightspeed and Shopify below as at September 2020:

Source: FireGrind

Brief key observations:

  • First and most importantly, the value proposition and branding: Nuvei position themselves as more of a payments technology facilitator that also provides merchant services meanwhile Lightspeed and Shopify are primarily focused on SMB merchants - to enable small businesses have successful online stores.

  • Customers: Shopify has a significant customer base of smaller business size at over 1Million compared to 77,000 for LSPD and 50,000 for Nuvei. Categories for customers is that Shopify serves mostly SMB’s, LSPD serves the retail & hospitality industry and Nuvei serves a wider variety of sectors with slightly bigger value clients.

  • On a profitability and efficiency perspective, I’ll note that Nuvei and Shopify are profitable on an operational basis, meanwhile Lightspeed is still making a loss.

  • Nuvei has superior gross margins at over 80% allowing them to retain more revenue for every dollar without adding more costs than their peers.

  • Overall, Shopify dominates this market growing rapidly despite being the largest behemoth, but Nuvei and Lightspeed appear to be closely aligned chasing for a close second in Canada.

BOTTOM LINE:   

The global adoption of eCommerce and mobile commerce is growing rapidly. It is said that it takes 40-66 days to form a habit. The change in customer habits and convenience of easily shopping online in 2020 is a behaviour that will not change anytime soon.

Nuvei has benefitted this year from the industry tailwinds. Some of the key positives with Nuvei is their proprietary native commerce platform that reduces friction for merchants and reduces cost. They are a global business across the world allowing further growth in countries with low eCommerce penetration. Based on a financial perspective, they are profitable on a operating basis than their peers, boast higher gross margins at 80%+ and management appears to be very efficient about the way they run the business. On the negative side, Nuvei’s unhappy customer reviews and issues could deter potential merchants and be beneficial for competitors.

The benefit of investing within this industry is that there is a major tailwind that allows all of these companies to be successful from the transformation in fintech. On a company valuation basis, Nuvei and Lightspeed at less than $10-Billion look attractive compared to Shopify at over $100B Market Cap. We can anticipate that over the next 3-5 years, Nuvei could provide shareholders and investors with a potential 10X return if they are able to execute well within their international markets and attain a quarter of the valuation of Shopify. To answer our initial question, I would say that so far it does not appear that Nuvei has what it takes to become a future Shopify anytime soon.  However, considering Nuvei’s strategy of going after complex vertical international markets within the niche payments ecosystem, I would not bet against them. They will be an interesting company to watch over the next couple of years.

What do you think about Nuvei, Shopify, Lightspeed?

Leave a comment

REMINDERS: Off next week and in January we reveal our top picks; Let me know if you have companies you want covered or analyzed. Subscribe today to receive future weekly company analysis on the top growing and innovative companies.

item.title: Dye & Durham: A Canadian high-tech company disrupting the legal industry
item.description: Company analysis
item.dc:creator: Francis
item.content:encoded:
This week on our Canadian edition, we will be reviewing a digital innovator within the legal technology industry. A sector that has rarely seen any major disruption from technology. This year, Dye and Durham raised eyebrows after its stock had a stellar performance on its debut on the Toronto Stock Exchange on July 17th surging over 97%.  The stock had the best trading debut for a large Canadian company in almost three decades since Lightspeed POS Inc.’s (next week, we’ll talk about the biggest IPO ever involving Nuvei on the TSE). This successful debut signifies very strong demand and interest from investors and institutions based on the company’s future prospects. Let’s explore and understand why this company has been successful.

ABOUT:

Dye and Durham. Stock ticker symbol (CAD: $DND.TO; USD: $DYNDF)

COMPANY DEFINITION & BREAKDOWN

Toronto-based Dye & Durham (“D&D”) is a cloud-based provider for legal and business professionals. Their digital software solutions digitize and automates legal manual tasks that ultimately seeks to improve the productivity and efficiency of law firms, and large institutions.

PRODUCT:

Dye and Durham’s software automates workflows and streamlines access to public records to support end-to-end legal transaction solutions that range from due diligence searches on an acquisition or financing to corporate registrations. For real-estate and home buying, their software automates many of the legal paperwork on the back end. For Financial institutions, it offers a range of technology-enabled risk mitigation solutions focused on “know-your-customer” and lien management. The image below describes their value proposition:

Customer: Dye and Durham software currently serves over 25,000 clients - law firms (including Canada’s top 20 legal firms), financial institutions such as the Bank of Nova Scotia, lenders, and government organizations. The client base is diversified with no individual customer representing more than 2 per cent of total revenue. Further, the company has a high customer retention rate with a churn rate (customer loss rate) of approximately 2 per cent. The average customer relationship is 16.6 years which is really impressive.

Business: The company has three primary business segments:

  • Business law – all the transactions that occur before major mergers and acquisitions (representing roughly 50 per cent of total revenue),

  • Real estate – all the back-end legal work involved in buying a new house or property (accounting for approximately one-third of total revenue)

  • Litigation solutions for the rest of their revenue. Revenue is largely generated from transactions.

Dye and Durham hopes to become the one-stop shop for all legal operations, automating public records, due diligence, security filings, litigations and court filings.

BUSINESS STRATEGY & COMPETITIVE EDGE

  • Dye & Durham has a growth by acquisition business model aimed at driving EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) growth.

  • Their strategy is too acquire, integrate and improve legal technology companies. They focus on acquiring targeted companies that fit their strategy, they integrate the companies to their existing operations and transform them into a top-tier legal tech company to serve their clients. Since the beginning of fiscal 2020 (the company’s year-end is June 30), management has completed five cloud-based acquisitions and a total of 19 since 2013.

  • A core competitive edge is their loyal and diversified blue-chip customer base which consists of the top law firms and financial institutions across Canada and the UK. This is a strong asset for D&D. It also creates a network effect because they have a strong understand of an industry or sector based on dealing with all the major players which makes their product sticky to existing customers.

  • Cloud-based offerings: Transitioning manual legal paperwork into a cloud/online is the future. Dye and Durham has a competitive edge as being one of the leader digitizing the legal industry.

  • Low competition in this industry strengthens it competitive advantage especially after it recently acquired one of its major competitor in Canada (more below).

FINANCIALS:

  • Between 2016 – 2019, they have compounded a 71% growth rate as indicated above and similarly improved their EBITDA margins which is impressive.  2020 YTD Revenue was $14.2-million, 22-million per cent year-over-year.  It is important to note that majority of their revenues have come from acquisitions made over the last few years and growth has slowed since the pandemic which the company attributes to Covid slowing down legal and business activity.

  • Professional analyst are forecasting revenue of $83.7 million in fiscal 2021, and $97.3-million in fiscal 2022.

  • Valuation is overextended as it trades around a market capitalization of around $2.06Billion on a Price-Sales ratio of 30.

  • The company will be paying its shareholders an annual dividend of of $0.01875 per common share.

INDUSTRY:

It is estimated the total addressable market for Dye & Durham within the legal and real estate market stands at around $12 billion for Canada, Australia, UK, Ireland and the US.

FUTURE & GROWTH & GROWTH POTENTIAL:

  • Expanding Globally: D&D already has a strong U.K. presence, but they have more room to grow. They recently announced a major acquisition of a major real-estate software provider in Australia, SAI Global Property division. The acquisition provides a large footprint for their presence in Australia.

  • Capturing more of the real estate market: They recently announced a major acquisition of DoProcess – widely regarded as the #1 provider of real estate practice management software in Canada managing over 1.4 million transactions annually.  It is a big player in Western Canada providing online workflow management software for real estate lawyers. With DoProcess, this is a transformative acquisition for the company because this was a key competitor, and it expands the services they offer customers.

  • Organic growth stems from cross-selling opportunities and price increases amongst its 25,000-customer base as price hikes are often passed on to customers.

MANAGEMENT TEAM:

We should note that the management team has “skin in the game.” as the CEO, Mathew Proud owns approximately 20 per cent of the shares outstanding through Plantro Ltd. This ensures that the leadership team makes decisions that aligns closely with that of shareholders and investors. The Board of Directors also includes Brad Wall, Former Premier of Saskatchewan.

RISKS:

  • High number of acquisitions: We are in a wait-and-see mode to see how well D&D can integrate the acquisitions they have made year-to-date, it’s now up to the team to execute. There are always significant challenges when acquiring multiple businesses. There are technical, business, and cultural challenges. Over the last couple of quarters, growth has slowed. It will be important to observe those numbers once the economy fully reopens for activity.

BOTTOM LINE

Dye and Durham is a digital company that is creating major efficiencies in a very “manual-like” industry. It has definitely created a niche for itself amongst its 25,000 customers and has managed to achieve a great level of product-market fit amongst large institutions such as the top law firms and financial institutions. Its competitive advantage is that it will be difficult for these large institutions to easily stop utilizing D&D’s software because of the knowledge, history, and value it provides to them. This is proven by the <2% low churn rate.

D&D also has a strong financial position. The company has sustained a proven track record of growing the business while achieving high operating margins. This is impressive when compared to its peers within the high growth technology industry.

The current valuation for Dye and Durham stock-price may be overextended at current prices, but for investors looking out over a 3-5 year horizon, this is a market leading company capable of doubling its stock valuation to become a $5Billion company based off its rapid growth. Investi Analyst is focused on finding digital disruptors with 10X potentials in modern new industries. Dye and Durham is poised to do well in a largely untapped legal industry.

What do you think about D&D? Let us know.
